title: Finding the Inverse
text:
Given a polynomial function, restrict the domain of a function that is not one-to-one and then find the inverse.
1) Restrict the domain by determining a domain on which the original function is one-to-one.
2) Replace f(x) with $$y$$.
3) Interchange $$x$$ and $$y$$.
4) Solve for $$y$$, and rename the function or pair of function $$f^{-1\left(xight)}$$.
5) Revise the formula for $$f^{-1\left(xight)}$$ by ensuring that the outputs of the inverse function correspond to the restricted domain of the original function.

Given a polynomial function, restrict the domain of a function that is not one-to-one and then find the inverse.

2) Replace f(x) with  y .
3) Interchange  x  and  y .
4) Solve for  y , and rename the function or pair of function , f raised to the negative 1 times x power .
5) Revise the formula for , f raised to the negative 1 times x power  by ensuring that the outputs of the inverse function correspond to the restricted domain of the original function.

title: Restricting the Domain
text: We can restrict this function to a domain on which it will be one-to-one.
speech: We can restrict this function to a domain on which it will be one-to-one.
pacedSpeech: We can restrict this function to a domain on which it will be one-to-one.

title: Restricting the Domain
text: We can see this is a parabola with vertex at $$(2,-3)$$ that opens upward. Because the graph will be decreasing on one side of the vertex and increasing on the other side, we can restrict this function to a domain on which it will be one-to-one by limiting the domain to $$x \geq 2$$.

title: Domain
text: Now we need to determine which case to use. Because we restricted our original function to a domain of $$x \geq 2$$, the outputs of the inverse should be the same, i.e. $$f^{-1\left(x\right)} \geq 2$$.

title: Domain
text: Which of the inverse would let us satisfy the initial domain of $$x \geq 2$$, i.e. for all $$x$$ in the domain of $$f^{-1\left(x\right)}$$, $$f^{-1\left(x\right)} \geq 2$$? Note that $$\sqrt{x}$$ is always greater than or equal to $$0$$.
